result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Reset Hearing from 11-3-2022 to on December 12, 2022 at 08:30 am due to conflict with court.  Confirmed with Atty. Hartley.
Hearing on November 3, 2022 at 08:30 am for position on prelim and change of plea.

Clerk: EZ. Defendant John J Norman III in court.  Attorney Christopher Hartley in court for John J Norman III.  Attorney Elizabeth A Longo in court for State of Wisconsin.  (21CF389 Br. 1; 22CF71 Br. 2)   Atty. Hartley is taking over on these cases and needs additional time to review all of the discovery but have a good understanding of the case and defendant has engaged in extensive AODA treatment and believe the cases will resolve and request adjournment to finalize plea negotiations.  State advises victim in 22CF71 is in court and objecting to a lengthy adjournment.  Court grants adjournment with anticipation that there will be progress on the adjourned date.
Plea hearing scheduled for November 3, 2022 at 08:30 am.
Plea hearing on November 3, 2022 at 08:30 am.

Clerk: EZ. Prosecuting attorney Elizabeth A Longo in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant John J Norman III in court.  Attorney Mark A. Pecora by Atty. Christopher Hartley appeared by video for John J Norman III.  (21CF389; 21TR2112; 21TR2113; 21TR2114; 21TR2115 Br. 1; 22CF55; 22FO56; 22FO57; Br. 3; 22CF71 Br. 2)  Victim appears in 22CF71.  Atty. Hartley states Atty. Pecora has retired and firm is looking at all the files from Atty. Pecora and wishing to have a meeting with the defendant to determine if he will maintain the firm and request an adjournment to discuss options and request 30-45 days to accomplish the issue.  State does not object.  State requests earlier time frame or late afternoon to accommodate the victim.
